title: Myasthenia Gravis - New Diagnosis
scope: ** Initial diagnostic workup and management of suspected or newly confirmed myasthenia gravis. Covers antibody testing, electrodiagnostic studies, thymoma screening, acute stabilization, and long-term immunotherapy initiation. For myasthenic crisis with respiratory failure, use "Myasthenic Crisis" template. For established MG on maintenance therapy, use "MG - Maintenance" template.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Thyroid disease co-occurs in 10-15% of MG; autoimmune overlap
Primary diagnostic test; positive in ~85% generalized MG, ~50% ocular MG
Complements binding/blocking; increases sensitivity to ~95% in generalized MG
Baseline; monitor for hemolysis on complement inhibitors

Extended Workup.rationale: Positive in ~40% of AChR-seronegative MG; distinct phenotype (bulbar, facial, neck weakness)
Positive in ~2-50% of double-seronegative MG; newer assay
Associated with thymoma in MG patients <40 years; screening marker
Associated with thymoma (especially in young-onset MG); late-onset MG marker
Associated with thymoma and severe MG
Screen for prior HBV before rituximab
Baseline before IVIG; monitor on rituximab/immunosuppression
Paraproteinemic neuropathy/NMJ screen in atypical cases
Baseline for hemolysis monitoring on complement inhibitors

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Novel antibody target in seronegative MG
Congenital myasthenic syndromes (CHRNE, DOK7, RAPSN, etc.) if onset <2 years or seronegative/atypical
Associated with myocarditis and severe MG phenotype (Japan)
If anterior mediastinal mass is atypical; tissue diagnosis

Essential/First-line.item: MRI chest with contrast (preferred over CT if available)

Essential/First-line.target: No mediastinal mass; baseline pulmonary status

Essential/First-line.timing: If unable to go to radiology

Extended.timing: During workup; stop pyridostigmine 12h prior if possible
Extended.target: Decremental response >10% at 2-3 Hz in proximal and distal muscles

Extended.timing: If RNS negative but clinical suspicion remains; most sensitive test (95-99%)
Extended.contraindications: Same as RNS; requires experienced electromyographer

Extended.timing: If diagnosis unclear; rule out neuropathy/myopathy
At bedside; apply ice to closed eyelid for 2 minutes
Extended.target: Improvement of ptosis by ≥2 mm (sensitivity ~80% for ocular MG)

Extended.timing: At bedside; rest with eyes closed for 2-5 minutes

dosing.instructions: Start 30 mg TID; increase by 30 mg per dose every 2-3 days; usual effective dose 60 mg q4-6h while awake; max 120 mg per dose (max ~960 mg/day, rarely needed)

Cholinesterase Inhibitors (Symptomatic).monitoring: Cholinergic side effects: diarrhea, cramping, salivation, bradycardia; cholinergic crisis if overdosed (weakness + muscarinic symptoms)

dosing.instructions: 180 mg qHS (sustained release); may give once or twice daily; do NOT crush

Cholinesterase Inhibitors (Symptomatic).monitoring: Same; useful for nocturnal/morning weakness; erratic absorption - use sparingly

dosing.instructions: Same dosing as IR; useful for patients with dysphagia
dosing.orderSentence: Pyridostigmine liquid (60 mg/5 mL) - - - see dosing

doseOptions.orderSentence: Neostigmine IV (if NPO or intubated) 0.5-2.5 mg IV

dosing.instructions: 0.5-2.5 mg IV/IM q1-3h; 1 mg IV neostigmine ≈ 30 mg oral pyridostigmine
dosing.orderSentence: Neostigmine IV (if NPO or intubated) 0.5-2.5 mg IV

Cholinesterase Inhibitors (Symptomatic).monitoring: Continuous cardiac monitoring; have atropine at bedside for bradycardia

doseOptions.orderSentence: Glycopyrrolate (for cholinergic side effects) 1-2 mg IV

dosing.instructions: 1-2 mg PO BID-TID or 0.1-0.2 mg IV PRN
dosing.orderSentence: Glycopyrrolate (for cholinergic side effects) 1-2 mg IV

Cholinesterase Inhibitors (Symptomatic).monitoring: Does NOT cross BBB (preferred over atropine for peripheral muscarinic side effects)

doseOptions.orderSentence: Atropine (for cholinergic side effects/emergency) 0.5-1 mg IV

dosing.instructions: 0.5-1 mg IV PRN for symptomatic bradycardia from pyridostigmine
dosing.orderSentence: Atropine (for cholinergic side effects/emergency) 0.5-1 mg IV

Cholinesterase Inhibitors (Symptomatic).monitoring: HR monitoring; crosses BBB (may cause confusion)

dosing.instructions: Hold or reduce if cholinergic crisis suspected (worsening weakness + excessive secretions)

Cholinesterase Inhibitors (Symptomatic).monitoring: Distinguish cholinergic crisis (excess pyridostigmine) from myasthenic crisis (undertreated MG)

doseOptions.orderSentence: Prednisone (gradual escalation - PREFERRED for outpatient) 10-20 mg PO

dosing.instructions: Start 10-20 mg daily; increase by 5-10 mg every 3-5 days to target 0.5-1 mg/kg/day (typically 40-60 mg daily); maintain 4-8 weeks then taper by 5-10 mg/month
dosing.orderSentence: Prednisone (gradual escalation - PREFERRED for outpatient) 10-20 mg PO

Corticosteroids (Immunosuppression - Ind.contraindications: Active untreated infection; uncontrolled diabetes; psychosis history
Corticosteroids (Immunosuppression - Ind.monitoring: Glucose (q6h inpatient, weekly outpatient); BP; mood/sleep; weight; bone density at baseline; GI prophylaxis

doseOptions.orderSentence: Prednisone (rapid escalation - INPATIENT preferred) 40-60 mg PO

dosing.instructions: Start 40-60 mg daily (0.75-1 mg/kg/day); CAUTION: may cause initial transient worsening in first 1-2 weeks
dosing.orderSentence: Prednisone (rapid escalation - INPATIENT preferred) 40-60 mg PO

Corticosteroids (Immunosuppression - Ind.monitoring: Same; MONITOR CLOSELY for steroid-induced exacerbation; consider concurrent IVIG/PLEX for protection

dosing.instructions: 1000 mg IV daily × 3-5 days; transition to oral prednisone taper

Corticosteroids (Immunosuppression - Ind.contraindications: Active untreated infection; uncontrolled diabetes; psychosis
Corticosteroids (Immunosuppression - Ind.monitoring: Glucose q6h (target <180); BP; mood; cardiac monitoring; GI prophylaxis

doseOptions.orderSentence: Omeprazole (GI prophylaxis during steroids) 20-40 mg PO

dosing.instructions: 20-40 mg daily while on steroids
dosing.orderSentence: Omeprazole (GI prophylaxis during steroids) 20-40 mg PO

dosing.instructions: Per protocol if glucose >180 mg/dL

doseOptions.orderSentence: Calcium carbonate + Vitamin D (bone protection) 1000-1200 mg PO

dosing.instructions: Calcium 1000-1200 mg + Vitamin D 1000-2000 IU daily while on chronic steroids
dosing.orderSentence: Calcium carbonate + Vitamin D (bone protection) 1000-1200 mg PO

Corticosteroids (Immunosuppression - Ind.monitoring: Serum calcium; consider DEXA if anticipated steroid course >3 months

doseOptions.orderSentence: Bisphosphonate (bone protection if chronic steroids) 70 mg PO

dosing.instructions: Alendronate 70 mg PO weekly OR risedronate 35 mg PO weekly; start if steroids expected >3 months
dosing.orderSentence: Bisphosphonate (bone protection if chronic steroids) 70 mg PO

Corticosteroids (Immunosuppression - Ind.contraindications: GFR <35; esophageal disorders; inability to remain upright 30 min
Corticosteroids (Immunosuppression - Ind.monitoring: DEXA at baseline; renal function; dental exam (ONJ risk)

dosing.instructions: 1 DS tablet (160/800 mg) daily or 3 times per week if prednisone ≥20 mg for ≥4 weeks

Corticosteroids (Immunosuppression - Ind.monitoring: CBC; renal function; use dapsone or atovaquone if allergic

dosing.instructions: Once stable on target dose for 4-8 weeks: decrease by 5-10 mg every 2-4 weeks until 20 mg, then decrease by 2.5-5 mg monthly; target lowest effective dose or off

Corticosteroids (Immunosuppression - Ind.contraindications: Do NOT stop abruptly if >2 weeks of therapy
Corticosteroids (Immunosuppression - Ind.monitoring: Adrenal insufficiency symptoms; disease flare; cortisol level if concerns

dosing.instructions: Start 500 mg BID; increase to 1000 mg BID after 2 weeks; target 2000-3000 mg/day in divided doses; onset 6-12 months

Steroid-Sparing Immunosuppressive Agents.monitoring: CBC q2 weeks × 3 months, then monthly; LFTs; GI side effects (diarrhea, nausea); lymphopenia; REMS pregnancy prevention

dosing.instructions: Start 50 mg daily; increase by 50 mg every 1-2 weeks to target 2-3 mg/kg/day (typically 150-250 mg/day); onset 6-18 months

Steroid-Sparing Immunosuppressive Agents.contraindications: TPMT deficiency (check before starting); concurrent allopurinol (reduce dose by 75%); pregnancy (relative)
Steroid-Sparing Immunosuppressive Agents.monitoring: TPMT genotype/activity BEFORE starting; CBC q1-2 weeks during titration, then monthly; LFTs; amylase/lipase if abdominal pain; lymphocyte count target 600-1000

dosing.instructions: Start 1 mg BID; titrate to trough level 5-10 ng/mL; onset 3-6 months (faster than MMF/AZA)

Steroid-Sparing Immunosuppressive Agents.monitoring: Trough levels; renal function q2 weeks then monthly; electrolytes (K, Mg); glucose; BP; tremor; nephrotoxicity

dosing.instructions: Start 2-3 mg/kg/day in 2 divided doses; target trough 100-150 ng/mL; onset 2-6 months

Steroid-Sparing Immunosuppressive Agents.contraindications: Uncontrolled hypertension; renal impairment; concurrent nephrotoxic drugs
Steroid-Sparing Immunosuppressive Agents.monitoring: Trough levels; renal function; BP; electrolytes (K, Mg); lipids; gingival hyperplasia; hirsutism

dosing.instructions: 10-20 mg PO or SC once weekly with folic acid 1 mg daily (except methotrexate day); onset 6-12 months

Steroid-Sparing Immunosuppressive Agents.contraindications: Pregnancy (Category X); hepatic disease; renal impairment (CrCl <30); concurrent trimethoprim
Steroid-Sparing Immunosuppressive Agents.monitoring: CBC q4 weeks; LFTs q8-12 weeks; renal function; pulmonary toxicity screen; folic acid supplementation mandatory

dosing.instructions: Pulse IV: 500-1000 mg/m² monthly × 6 months; OR oral 1-2 mg/kg/day; reserved for refractory MG

Steroid-Sparing Immunosuppressive Agents.contraindications: Pregnancy; active infection; bone marrow suppression
Steroid-Sparing Immunosuppressive Agents.monitoring: CBC weekly during treatment; urinalysis (hemorrhagic cystitis - MESNA with IV dosing); fertility counseling; malignancy risk

dosing.instructions: 1-2 g/kg divided over 2-5 days, then 0.4-1 g/kg every 4 weeks as maintenance

Steroid-Sparing Immunosuppressive Agents.contraindications: IgA deficiency (check IgA level first); recent thrombotic event; renal failure
Steroid-Sparing Immunosuppressive Agents.monitoring: Pre-infusion: IgA level, renal function, CBC; during: vital signs q15 min first hour; headache; aseptic meningitis; thrombosis risk; renal function

dosing.instructions: 375 mg/m² IV weekly × 4 weeks; OR 1000 mg IV × 2 doses 14 days apart; re-dose when CD19/CD20 recover or clinical worsening; onset 3-6 months

Biologics, Complement Inhibitors & Rescu.contraindications: Active Hepatitis B; active infection; severe immunodeficiency
Biologics, Complement Inhibitors & Rescu.monitoring: HBV serology before; CD19/CD20 counts q3-6 months; immunoglobulins q6 months; PML risk (very rare); infusion reactions (premedicate with acetaminophen, diphenhydramine, methylprednisolone)

dosing.instructions: 900 mg IV weekly × 4 weeks, then 1200 mg IV at week 5, then 1200 mg IV every 2 weeks; for AChR-positive generalized MG

Biologics, Complement Inhibitors & Rescu.contraindications: Unresolved Neisseria meningitidis infection; unvaccinated against meningococcus
Biologics, Complement Inhibitors & Rescu.monitoring: Meningococcal vaccine ≥2 weeks before; REMS program; CBC; LDH/reticulocyte (hemolysis on discontinuation); signs of meningococcal infection; ciprofloxacin prophylaxis recommended

dosing.instructions: Weight-based loading dose IV, then maintenance every 8 weeks; for AChR-positive generalized MG

Biologics, Complement Inhibitors & Rescu.monitoring: Same as eculizumab; less frequent dosing advantage

dosing.instructions: 0.3 mg/kg SC daily (self-administered); for AChR-positive generalized MG

Biologics, Complement Inhibitors & Rescu.monitoring: Same meningococcal vaccination required; injection site reactions; LDH; reticulocyte count

dosing.instructions: 10 mg/kg IV weekly × 4 weeks per cycle; may repeat based on clinical response; for AChR-positive generalized MG

Biologics, Complement Inhibitors & Rescu.monitoring: IgG levels (expect ~70% reduction); infection monitoring; no meningococcal vaccine required

dosing.instructions: 1008 mg efgartigimod + 11,200 units hyaluronidase SC weekly × 4 weeks per cycle

Biologics, Complement Inhibitors & Rescu.monitoring: Same; injection site reactions; self-administered option

dosing.instructions: Weight-based SC weekly × 6 weeks per cycle; for AChR-positive generalized MG

Biologics, Complement Inhibitors & Rescu.monitoring: IgG levels; headache common; pyrexia; infection monitoring

dosing.instructions: 5-7 exchanges over 10-14 days; exchange 1-1.5 plasma volumes per session

Biologics, Complement Inhibitors & Rescu.contraindications: Hemodynamic instability; sepsis; line contraindication; heparin allergy
Biologics, Complement Inhibitors & Rescu.monitoring: BP during exchange; electrolytes (Ca, K, Mg); coagulation studies; fibrinogen; line site infection; hypotension

dosing.instructions: 2 g/kg divided over 2-5 days (e.g., 0.4 g/kg/day × 5 days)

Biologics, Complement Inhibitors & Rescu.contraindications: IgA deficiency; renal failure; recent thrombotic event
Biologics, Complement Inhibitors & Rescu.monitoring: Pre-infusion IgA level; renal function; vital signs; headache (aseptic meningitis); thrombosis risk

Surgical Treatment.indication: AChR-positive generalized MG, age 18-65 (MGTX trial); any age with thymoma; consider in AChR-positive ocular MG with suboptimal response
Surgical Treatment.contraindications: MuSK-positive MG (no proven benefit); medically unstable; uncontrolled MG (optimize first)
Surgical Treatment.monitoring: MGTX trial: thymectomy + prednisone superior to prednisone alone at 3 years; optimize MG before surgery (FVC >2L, no bulbar crisis); post-op ICU monitoring recommended

Surgical Treatment.indication: Thymoma requiring complete resection; invasive thymoma
Surgical Treatment.monitoring: More invasive; complete thymoma staging with Masaoka classification; consider neoadjuvant chemotherapy for advanced thymoma
Includes removal of all anterior mediastinal fat; en bloc resection

Referrals & Consults.indication: All new MG diagnoses for treatment planning and long-term management
Thymoma present; AChR-positive generalized MG for thymectomy discussion
Respiratory compromise; pre-thymectomy pulmonary evaluation; chronic respiratory monitoring
Bulbar symptoms: dysphagia, dysarthria, nasal speech; aspiration risk
ADL impairment; energy conservation; adaptive equipment
Generalized weakness; deconditioning; fall prevention; exercise prescription
Ocular MG; diplopia management; prism evaluation
Concurrent autoimmune disease (lupus, RA, thyroid disease)
Steroid-induced diabetes; thyroid disease management; osteoporosis
Depression; anxiety; adjustment to chronic diagnosis; steroid-induced psychiatric symptoms
Insurance navigation (biologic cost); disability evaluation; MG support resources
FVC/NIF monitoring; ventilator management; BiPAP/CPAP evaluation
Dysphagia diet modification; weight management on steroids; nutritional optimization
Pre-operative assessment; avoidance of neuromuscular blocking agents; post-op ventilation planning
IVIG scheduling; rituximab infusion; complement inhibitor infusions
Chronic pain from sustained muscle weakness or comorbid conditions
Severely refractory MG with significant symptom burden; goals of care discussion
Patient support groups; educational materials; myasthenia.org referral

Patient Instructions.item: Return to ED immediately if difficulty breathing, swallowing, or speaking
Return to ED if new severe weakness, double vision worsening acutely, or unable to hold head up
Take pyridostigmine 30-60 minutes BEFORE meals to help with chewing and swallowing
Do NOT take pyridostigmine more frequently than prescribed (cholinergic crisis risk)
Report excessive salivation, diarrhea, cramping, or muscle twitching (cholinergic side effects)
Carry MG medical alert identification at all times
Provide MG medication list to ALL healthcare providers (emergency, dental, surgical)
Avoid extreme heat, hot baths/saunas (may worsen weakness)
Plan activities for times of best strength (usually morning after pyridostigmine)
Rest before meals if dysphagia present; eat smaller, more frequent meals
Do NOT stop prednisone or immunosuppressant abruptly (adrenal crisis/flare risk)
Avoid alcohol (potentiates weakness and interacts with medications)
Report any signs of infection immediately (fever, cough, dysuria) especially if on immunosuppression
Contact neurologist before taking any new medications (many drugs worsen MG)
Do NOT use over-the-counter magnesium-containing products without physician approval
Keep emergency contact numbers for MG specialist readily available
Understand the difference between myasthenic crisis and cholinergic crisis
Monitor and report progressive difficulty climbing stairs, rising from chairs, or lifting arms above head

differential.features: Proximal weakness with improvement after exertion (facilitation); autonomic dysfunction; dry mouth; associated with SCLC; depressed reflexes that improve post-exercise
differential.tests: VGCC antibody (P/Q-type); incremental response on RNS at 50 Hz; CT chest for malignancy

differential.features: Acute onset descending paralysis; dilated/fixed pupils; recent ingestion of canned food or wound; autonomic dysfunction; no prior NMJ disease
differential.tests: Stool/serum botulinum toxin assay; EMG: BSAP pattern; incremental response on high-frequency RNS

differential.features: Childhood onset; family history; seronegative; variable inheritance patterns; specific gene mutations
differential.tests: Genetic testing (CMS gene panel: CHRNE, DOK7, RAPSN, CHAT, COLQ); no autoantibodies

differential.features: Proptosis; restrictive (not fatigable) diplopia; lid lag; thyroid dysfunction; MRI shows enlarged EOMs
differential.tests: TSH, free T4, TSI, orbital MRI showing EOM enlargement (not NMJ issue)

differential.features: Slowly progressive bilateral ptosis and ophthalmoparesis; non-fatigable; no diurnal variation; may have pigmentary retinopathy
differential.tests: Muscle biopsy (ragged red fibers, COX-negative); mitochondrial DNA analysis

differential.features: Late-onset (>40) progressive ptosis and dysphagia; autosomal dominant; no fatigability; specific ethnic prevalence (French-Canadian, Bukharan Jewish)
differential.tests: Genetic testing (PABPN1 gene, GCN trinucleotide repeat); CK may be mildly elevated

differential.features: Progressive weakness without fatigability; fasciculations; UMN signs (hyperreflexia, Babinski); no sensory loss; bulbar onset may mimic MG
differential.tests: EMG/NCS: active denervation, fasciculations; normal RNS; no antibodies

differential.features: Proximal weakness without fatigability; elevated CK; skin findings in DM; no ptosis/diplopia (usually); IBM with grip/quad weakness
differential.tests: CK; myositis antibody panel; EMG: myopathic pattern; muscle biopsy

differential.features: Acute onset; cranial nerve palsies without fatigability; other focal neurological signs; vascular risk factors
differential.tests: Brain MRI with DWI; MRA; CTA

differential.features: Acute ophthalmoplegia, ataxia, areflexia; post-infectious; no fatigability
differential.tests: Anti-GQ1b antibody; CSF albuminocytologic dissociation; NCS (reduced SNAPs)

differential.features: Ptosis and facial weakness; myotonia (delayed relaxation); distal > proximal weakness; cataracts; cardiac conduction abnormalities
differential.tests: Genetic testing (DMPK CTG repeat for DM1, CNBP CCTG repeat for DM2); EMG: myotonic discharges

differential.features: Progressive proximal and distal weakness; hyporeflexia/areflexia; sensory involvement; elevated CSF protein
differential.tests: NCS: demyelinating pattern; CSF protein; nerve biopsy

differential.features: Granulomatous myopathy or cranial neuropathy; systemic involvement (lungs, skin, eyes); elevated ACE
differential.tests: ACE level; chest CT; biopsy (non-caseating granulomas); gallium scan

differential.features: Temporal correlation with offending drug (D-penicillamine, checkpoint inhibitors, statins); antibodies may be present
differential.tests: Drug history; antibody testing; improvement after drug withdrawal

evidence.recommendation: AChR antibody testing for MG diagnosis
evidence.source: [Gilhus NE et al. Nat Rev Dis Primers 2019](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/31048702/)

evidence.recommendation: AChR binding + blocking + modulating antibodies increases sensitivity to ~95%
evidence.source: Howard JF. Clinical Overview of MG. UpToDate 2024

evidence.recommendation: MuSK antibody testing in seronegative MG
evidence.source: [Hoch W et al. Nat Med 2001](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/11231638/); [Evoli A et al. Brain 2003](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/12821509/)
[Higuchi O et al. Ann Neurol 2011](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/21387385/); [Zisimopoulou P et al. J Autoimmun 2014](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/24373505/)
AANEM Practice Parameter 2001; Sanders DB et al.

evidence.recommendation: Ice pack test for ocular MG (~80% sensitivity)
CT chest for thymoma screening in all MG patients
evidence.source: [Gilhus NE et al. Nat Rev Dis Primers 2019](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/31048702/); AAN Guidelines
[Evoli A et al. Brain 2003](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/12821509/); Guptill JT et al. 2011

evidence.recommendation: Steroid-induced transient worsening in ~50% of MG patients
evidence.source: Bae JS et al. Muscle Nerve 2006

evidence.evidenceLevel: Class I (negative RCTs but widely used)
evidence.source: Sanders DB et al. Neurology 2008; MG Study Group (note: RCTs were short-duration)
[Diaz-Manera J et al. Neurology 2012](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/22218276/); [Hehir MK et al. Neurology 2017](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/28801338/)
Tandan R et al. (BeatMG trial) Lancet Neurol 2023

evidence.recommendation: IVIG for MG acute exacerbation and maintenance
IVIG equivalent to PLEX for MG exacerbation
MGTX trial: thymectomy + prednisone superior at 3 years
evidence.source: [Wolfe GI et al. NEJM 2016](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/27509100/); 5-year extension data 2019

evidence.recommendation: Medications to avoid in MG (comprehensive review)
evidence.source: [Gilhus NE. NEJM 2016](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/28029925/); Sheikh S et al. Muscle Nerve 2021

evidence.recommendation: FVC <15 mL/kg predicts need for intubation
NIF weaker than -20 cm H2O: intubation threshold
QMG score as validated outcome measure
evidence.source: [Barohn RJ et al. Ann NY Acad Sci 1998](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/9668327/)
[Norwood F et al. J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry 2014](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/23757420/); [Batocchi AP et al. Neurology 1999](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/10025772/)

evidence.recommendation: Transient neonatal MG in 10-20% of births

monitoring.frequency: Q4-6h in acute; Q shift if stable
monitoring.action: If <15 mL/kg or <1 L: impending respiratory failure, prepare for intubation; ICU transfer

monitoring.frequency: Q4-6h in acute; Q shift if stable
monitoring.action: If weaker than -20 cm H2O: intubate; -20 to -30 = ICU monitoring
Supplemental O2; BiPAP; intubation if declining

monitoring.frequency: Daily; each meal if bulbar symptoms
monitoring.action: NPO if aspiration risk; NG tube or modified diet; SLP consult

monitoring.frequency: Q shift inpatient; BID in ICU
monitoring.action: If worsening: reassess pyridostigmine dose; consider IVIG/PLEX; check for cholinergic crisis
Insulin sliding scale; endocrine consult if persistent >250
Infection workup if febrile (infection is leading MG crisis trigger)
Replace aggressively; hypokalemia and hypomagnesemia worsen NMJ transmission

monitoring.frequency: Continuous if on neostigmine IV; during PLEX
monitoring.action: Atropine for bradycardia; PLEX can cause electrolyte-mediated arrhythmias
HOB elevated; thickened liquids; SLP-guided diet

disposition.criteria: Mild symptoms (ocular only or mild generalized); FVC >60% predicted and stable; adequate oral intake; pyridostigmine optimized; reliable follow-up within 1-2 weeks; understands return precautions; crisis action plan reviewed

Moderate generalized weakness; FVC 40-60% predicted and stable; dysphagia requiring diet modification but tolerating PO; new diagnosis requiring expedited workup; steroid initiation with concern for transient worsening; IVIG infusion
FVC 30-40% predicted or declining trend; moderate bulbar symptoms; starting PLEX; significant comorbidities requiring closer monitoring; recent cholinergic vs myasthenic crisis distinction unclear

FVC <30% predicted or <1 L; NIF weaker than -25 cm H2O; progressive respiratory failure; impending intubation; active myasthenic crisis; severe bulbar dysfunction with aspiration; hemodynamic instability during PLEX
PLEX needed but unavailable; neuromuscular specialist not available; ICU capability needed but not present; thymectomy needed at specialized center

FVC >50% predicted and improving; adequate oral intake; stable on oral medications; immunotherapy plan established; outpatient follow-up scheduled within 1-2 weeks; patient and family educated on crisis recognition
